I have looked at a lot of videos about colonizing the moon & Mars. And I haven't found any with my same ideas. I think we should set up a moon colony on earth. We should have inflatable domes, which we cover with 3D printers with simulated moon mortar. The domes should be connected to each other by inflatable tunnels covered with simulated moon mortar. There should be living quarters, hydroponic green houses, gardens with garden soil for recreational gardening, a 5 acre pasture with one inch of garden soil and one inch of grass turf, a park with artificial turf and with small sections of real grass turf, and maybe even a very small zoo. All the domes will have plastic floors so no water is lost. Condensation forming on the ceilings will be drained into the water supply. All the domes will be blown up with compressed air from earth and will have a refresh system, which will refresh the air and maintain the air pressure. Humidity, Temperature will be maintained by humidifiers, heaters, fans and coolers. Light will be provided by multi-color LEDs, mostly white. Power will be supplied at first by solar power, and later by nuclear or fusion power. All water will be re-cycled, almost zero loss of water. There will be a bull, a cow, two sheep, and two goats, two chickens, two turkeys, two fish, and two rabbits. There will also be pets, two dogs, two cats, two bunnies, etc. (and maybe a small zoo) All of this will be set up by astronauts and robots before the colonist arrive.

The first colonist will be 5 fathers and 5 mothers, and 90 babies. The parents will be good parents, gardeners, farmers, zoo keepers, teachers, etc.. During the first two years an exact duplicate facility will be built on the moon. When the babies are two years old, they will move to the moon and live on the moon. Or if it is proven that they will be too young to travel to the moon than the facility on earth will be added to, to accommodate 10 more parents and 90 more babies. The two year olds would move into the new addition. Every two years the facility will be either added to, or 100 people will move to the moon. This plan will allow the kids to grow up in the isolation of the colony, and will make it easier for them to live in the isolation of the colony on the moon. And will allow them to grow up on the moon and be better able to adjust to the lower gravity on the moon, although some artificial gravity maybe eventually provided. This artificial gravity will especially be good for the parents. The kids will have everything in the facility to keep them occupied and entertained. Also they could have some books, movies, games, etc., especially adapted for them, being careful not to give them anything that would make them feel isolated.

After 20 years there could be 2000 people living on the moon, most of whom grew up on the moon. This program could be speeded up so in 20 years there could be 4000, 6000, or 8000 people living on the moon.

This program could be simultaneously done to colonize Mars so we could have 2000 people on the Moon and Mars at the same time. For the moon we could send supplies every month, but for Mars we could only send supplies every 26 months. So I suggest we send 10, 20, or 30 rockets to Mars every 26 months all at the same time.

We could have several refueling stations along the way to mars and orbiting mars so rockets could refuel along the way to mars and right before landing on mars so the empty rocket would have enough fuel to take off again, refuel in space and return to Earth. Eventually the colonist could grow trees, bamboo, and other plants for raw materials that could be used for making things. Eventually the moon and Mars could export minerals or small expensive items that were assembled on the moon or Mars, like jewelry, iphones, iwatches, etc. Or grown on the moon like caviar, marijuana, etc.

I recall taking a training session we had to take at work on getting our software validated for government QA programs, and talking to the instructor between parts and he asked us what our software development strategy was, and I described mine, basically get something working quickly to help me be sure I understood what I'm doing, and he said that's called "Incrementalism", so I accept it. You almost have to write software twice, the first time to solve the problem, and a second time you can write it correctly when you know what it looks like, although in practice often you never rewrite, and just end up with an underdesigned system that ends up burdening future development that has to adjust to the underplanned limitations. Still, I agree with the approach - very few people are smart enough to design from nothing and get it right the first time.

You can tell this is Elon's sanctuary; in the field with his rockets. It's not the rocket so much that excites him, but the future it represents. His mind is 50 years in the future, and to his dismay, his body is stuck in the present.

He is often questioned by interviewers with present-centered minds, in awe of his far reaching ideas of the future. These interviews often take place on a stage in some studio by some media outlet locked in on 'current' events. Passionate people express themselves the most when everything around them lights them up, so enter their space if you want a great interview. For Elon, this is where you can see the sky and smell the rocket fuel, the sensations that bring him to the edge of current reality. You need only ask 1 question; What do you see, and how do we get there? In spilling the contents of his mind, he'll give you all the followup questions you need. There's no need for a script.

Learnings on this interview:
1.) How to make things go fast – If the design is taking too long then the design is wrong and therefore the design must be modified to accelerate progress.
2.) Errors made that hinders advancing development – stick to a design even when it is very complicated and to not strive delete parts and processes (not essential to its progress).
3.) Product errors reflect organizational errors - the constraints you are given (talking about departmental interfaces) are guaranteed to be some degree wrong because the counterpoint would be that they are perfect which is never the case. What is the probability that this is a platonic ideal of a perfect part? Zero, so basically you must question your constraints. It does not matter if the person handling you those constraints won a noble prize, even Einstein is wrong some time. So question your constraints and this is extremely important.
4.) Mistakes smart engineers make – biggest traps for smart engineers is optimizing a thing that shouldn’t exist. So they’ll just sit there and spin on that thing that’s just like, “Why do we even have this in the first place?”
5.) Finding answers – Once you properly frame the question the answer is comparatively easy.
6.) If proven wrong – considers it a gift. Don’t want to stick a dumb design if proven there is better way to do it.

Has Elon ever considered landing the Starship on its side?  The boosters tend to want to topple so why not take advantage of that with Starship. Using the same tech they use for the boosters let it descend until it's near the ground. Then extend three sets of landing gear on one side of the rocket. That will make it tend to fall to that side and thrusters can then take over and level the craft horizontally, much like a jump jet, so it can land on its side on the landing gear. A stairway can then be lowered from the crew quarters to the ground instead of the long elevator they are currently envisioning. Resting on 6 landing gear in two rows of three they can slip a flatbed beneath the vehicle to take it for refurbishment or raise it back vertically for relaunch.  The long elevator to the ground seems to be the vulnerable portion of the plan as an astronaut risks getting stranded on the surface without any way to get back on the ship.  A Harrier jet was about 2.6 tons landing vertically.  Starship is about 260 tons near empty and that's like 100 Harriers.  On the moon the Starship would be about 41 tons.  VTOL tech would have advanced since the Harrier.

Elon Reeve Musk é um empreendedor, filantropo e visionário sul-africano-canadense-americano. Ele é o fundador, CEO e CTO da SpaceX; CEO da Tesla Motors; vice-presidente da OpenAI; fundador e CEO da Neuralink; e co-fundador e presidente da SolarCity. Este homem será o responsável por salvar milhares de pessoas. A Nasa vem a anos estudando pra explorar um planeta e chega Elon Reeve Musk em pouco tempo já conseguiu reaproveitar  seus foguetes de lançamentos. Fazendo com isso a viabilidade de exploração deixar de ser um sonho e tornar realidade. Hoje estou aqui escrevendo a minha opinião sobre esta  realidade. Elon Reeve Musk você vai passar por várias  barreiras, mas nenhuma delas serão o suficiente para que façam desistir dos outros planetas. No universo existe sim vida além de nós. Podem ser iguais ou diferente de nós, mas isso não importa o objetivo e migrar para outro planeta porque o nosso aos poucos esta se modificando com os passar dos anos. Não podemos dormir e esperar que tudo sempre continue como esta a cada dia que passa modificações acontecem. Precisamos buscar outro caminho além das estrelas. Neste imenso universo existe sim vida igual a nossa sim! Apesar de que algumas pessoas defendam que isso é impossível. Você Elon Reeve Musk acredita que existe vida em outros planetas? Então acompanho sempre seus passos sou super fã admiro sua coragem em perder seu tempo precioso em busca de uma solução para humanidade. Quero lhe agradecer e lhe dizer que você vai encontrar o que procura em breve neste universo imenso. A humanidade só tem a lhe agradecer por nos ajudar. Talvez eu e você Elon Reeve Musk não estaremos aqui pra ver a conquista espacial no futuro. Mas estaremos na história eu Luiz Paulek por escrever esta carta a você Elon Reeve Musk por conquistar o espaço e salvar a espécie humana. Bom meu amigo Elon desejo todo sucesso do mundo a você e nunca desista vá em frente. Precisamos de você lembra disso. O primeiro passo você, já deu o segundo será pousar em Marte com seres humanos a bordo de uma nave que você vai construir. Marte é só o começo da exploração espacial de longa distância. Lembre de mim quando for lançar as pessoas rumo a Marte. Que Deus te abençoe em sua jornada espacial. Que a humanidade sempre lembre de você como o responsável por salvar a raça humana. Lembra desta frase "AVENTUREIRO PAULEK" no lançamento da Starship. Obrigado Elon Reeve Musk e muito sucesso com a Spacex!

I have a question about annealing the steel. SpaceX intends to use cold rolled 301 stainless steel for the starship. The cold rolling work hardens the material, and can be removed by annealing the material- bringing it up to a high temperature and cooling it. There are different types and levels of annealing, but 301 stainless can be annealed by heating it to as little as 500 °F and then slowly cooling it. Higher temperatures would be more effective at annealing the material, of course- I believe annealing is related to the temperature squared or something like that. Every trip would raise the steel to at least 500 °F- likely much higher- and slow cool it, removing the strength of the material. How could SpaceX avoid this issue of annealing? How hot could the steel be getting?

I remember when my 4 year old daughter asked about 🎅.
She came to me on the front pourch and said "Dad I've been thinking about Santa..And I'm sure he's not real. Is he real or not?"
Whew....that's a big question to answer someone so young.
Her mother did not approved of my answer. I said "Honey what you feel is right about 🎅." She said "Thought so...thank you Dad."
Then she went to school and had several discussions about it. which turned into a mob scene, basically.
You see some people want the truth.
Most don't. And will only grip the lie more tightly when you tell them they have believed in a lie. Something they put there hopes in, their dreams in, something that makes them escape reality, something that they share with others....
A shared delusion.
And they will attack.
But, sometimes after the dust settles there is one...maybe more. That say within themselves. Something rang true about what they said.
And they may have the courage, curiosity, or just hunger for the truth. No matter where it leads. To follow.
To whomever reads this.
This is all sci-fi. Equivalent to the Easter 🐰, or Santa, or the tooth fairy.
It is nothing more than a production.
To make you go oh.......ah.....

1. If a design is taking too long, the design is wrong - 01:52
2. Strive to delete parts and processes - 02:05
3. Ignore sunk costs, ask “Is this in the future or not, if not, who cares?” - 02:25
4. Everyone is chief engineer - 03:27
5. The product errors reflect the organizational errors - 03:41
6. What is the probability that this is the most perfect specification ever devised? Always question constraints given to you by other groups - 04:04
7. Most common issue – Optimizing a thing that shouldn’t exist - 05:00
8. With all the degrees of freedom of reality, the default approach to any question should be to evaluate whether the question is the correct one to ask. - 05:17
9. Hitchhikers Guide To the Galaxy Principle: at the point in which you can properly frame the question, the answer is comparatively easy. - 05:35

I love hearing Elon's philosophy spelled out, perhaps a lot because he confirms so many of my own deep held beliefs about how stuff should be done. But until you see a guy as successful as Elon Musk you really don't have any kind of proof of what you feel instinctively to be true.

His thoughts around simple design and question assumptions are profound I think. I think simple designs are really key to success. It seems obvious, yet people still end up making extremely complex systems.However I don't think I have really connected the dots about why we tend to end up with complex designs so often.

I think the "sunk cost" fallacy is a lot to blame. You go down one road, and when things end up being far more complicated than you imagine, you don't dear scrapping what you have done and start over. You believe you have invested so much in what you are currently doing that just keep going, adding more and more complexity.

Although I am building software rather than rockets, I think the same principles of simplicity are extremely useful. I think in general we find that people end up being more productive using simple programming languages. But people too often get pulled along by the sirene song of more features ending up choosing more complex languages, libraries etc. People always seem terrified of the prospect of not having enough features. In the short term it is not obvious why all the extra features are not going to be worth it in the long run.

3:47 - "The product errors reflect the organizational errors. ... Whatever departments you've got, that will be where your interfaces are. ... Instead of questioning the constraints, one department will design to the constraints that another department has given them, without calling into question those constraints. ... You should actually take the approach that the constraints that you are given are guaranteed to be some degree wrong. ... Because the counterpoint would be that they are perfect."
As an engineer, I agree with this so much. In case anyone is wondering, this is why the government keeps creating new agencies, because new needs arise periodically, and getting multiple pre-existing teams to work as a single unit to solve a new problem when those teams have different chains of command never works well. The same thing happens in private businesses of course, but private businesses don't require a literal Act of Congress to dissolve pre-existing teams that are no longer effective, so the reorganization process is much harder in the government.

My biggest beef with aerospikes is that they inherently have a large area of wall exposed to high heat flux, much more than in a conventional engine. This heat flux is too high to allow use of aluminum, and the large copper parts with lots of metal volume are massive, as well as structurally inefficient. Annular throat designs like the J2T, in particular, have huge cmopressive loads on parts loaded in buckling, requiring lots of stiffening members- which adds even more mass. Aerospikes are inevitably bulkier and heavier than simple engines, and only do a so-so job of altitude compensation.

I don’t understand why everyone is so focused on building these massive rockets that would launch from Earth, travel the solar system and then come back to land on the Earth. It just seems to me that, in the long run, it would be cheaper to build a space station that could dock and refuel these massive ships in space. SpaceX could use their smaller rockets to transport fuel, personnel, and supplies to the space station just like they are doing for ISS (minus personnel).

Then you can make a quick and cheap turn around to the moon. We can perfect colonization on the moon before we try sending humans so f-ing far away (Mars).

We can then learn low G mining and production techniques on the moon and use these technologies to build TRULY interplanetary ships using nuclear engines and launched from lunar orbit.

Nice aerospike discussion. Personally I think close to vacuum nozzle sizes and water injection at low altitudes, possibly with injection in such a way as to provide a thick film of cooler lower velocity but high mass flow to keep the nozzle away from flow separation and provide a shield of lower velocity flow to reduce sound and vibration, much as the outer flow of a high bypass jet reduces noise (maybe scallop the edges of the nozzle too). Note the purpose is not so much film cooling as keeping the volume of flow high enough. More thrust at low altitude at a penalty of lower isp, with the mass flow of water reducing to nothing at perhaps 10 or 12 km altitude. More vacuum engines and fewer SL engines. If injection is into the throat area and a bit downstream the water could come from pressurized tanks at much lower pressure than in the turbomachinery.

It's like every other interview is 30mph residential area, where he has to keep stopping to explain basic physics and rocketry concepts to the interviewer and the audience.
And this is Autobahn-No limit, the interviewer and the audience already understand that stuff so he can just go full speed.

5:15 I actually had that experience in college (high speed aero/fluids) where the professor had presented the question as "you are designing a supersonic orifice for a wind tunnel, we need to get the dimensions" - this is a case where the equations spit out an orifice cross sectional area and you have to figure out the dimensions.

He then began running this series of converging area-dimension solving equations with a classmate at the board and they were slogging their way through this iteration...going over then under, etc. and converging down to an answer that seemed really mathematically ambiguous.

I think the area from the flow equation was something like 12 cm^2 .... so, working on it at my desk, I'd long since thought "well, I'll make this simple and assume my test chamber is 4cm wide and so the other dimension is 3cm... simple. ....ok and (looking up at the exercise they were doing) ... what on EARTH are they doing up there????"

I raised my hand and said "Why are you doing it this way? You said we're DESIGNING this thing, so why not just choose one of the dimensions ARBITRARILY ...because if you're designing it then you do get to choose at some point ... and let the other dimension fall out"

He stared at me blankly for a few moments and then the light bulb clicked on. We discussed it as a class a bit further but then agreed that you certainly could take it on that way --- he just hadn't considered that way of simplifying the problem.

Though he took the last word by pointing out that sometimes you can't just pick a dimension so you will have to know how to solve for it. Fair.

As I understand it, the main advantage of aerospike engines would be decreasing the launch mass, not increasing engine efficiency. Instead of having two sets of engines, one for sea level and one for vacuum, as Starship will, an aerospike engine could use just one engine for both. The reasons that nobody has done this are 1) the advantage over the complexity isn't that great and 2) nobody has done this, so why start now.

Elon's comment about the tanks being integrated into the fuselage structure is interesting: he's right in that the old-school rockets basically treated the tanks as cargo mostly because the first rocket designs didn't even HAVE an external skin for a variety of reasons and the first step towards making the designs aerodynamic were to simply cover the engines and tanks with a skin. That design philosophy basically stuck and I guess the thought is that it allowed for an extra level of safety (two layers), perhaps calculating volume was easier when the volume was already built to suit, and it permitted different components to be manufactured separately.


I'd be curious to know more about the structural integrity of this rocket... without adequate internal pressure, the lighter you make the craft, the greater the possibility of the rocket collapsing or bending... is there an interior structure that makes it rigid enough to survive all the different kinds of stresses that it will encounter? How strong is this puppy?


Also, will the final construction process result in a craft that is essentially seamless or require less welds? I really need to look this stuff up...

In a relatively small component , that simply couldn't be done in a traditional company, with their silos,  but because Tesla's departments effectively merge the departmental interfaces, they are able to achieve far better product harmony and optimisation than anybody else in the field. Nicely done!   I do wish someone would talk more about safety issues for crewed flights given the speed of development. I feel like its been un-designed. Questions like: Systems and life support redundancy? Abort up to 60 seconds after launch - booster failure - how do they get off? Anyone Xray all those welds? Expected metallurgy stress and metal fatigue with high re-use cycle rates of engines and air frame? During crewed orbital flight tests, what's the rescue plan if there is an air frame or other failure into orbit? What happens if they break a fin - can they still de-orbit with control? When all the artists go to the moon - how do they transfer to another rescue spacecraft of something breaks - or can they -  will they have training and proper suits? And so on.  While the NASA paradigm is totally different, every time they were hell bent and they rushed schedules people died.  After all the ohhhs and ahhhhs: lots and lots of people are going to fly in these spacecraft and I wish we'd hear more about Elon's insistence on safety vs speed.

For the most part I really don't like the modern crop of entrepreneurs who seem focused on squeezing a dime out of everything and when interviewed use boardroom language like "synergy" and "paradigm shift" and never really say anything useful. Elon Musk on the other hand is like a kid in a candy store when it comes to the stuff his companies make and just comes across as excited and too lost in the idea of making great things happen to "do an interview" that is just a PR thing. It's entertaining, informative, and exciting to hear him talk about SpaceX. It's hard to not just like the guy. He believes in what he is doing, and yeah maybe he is a little crazy when it comes to time frames and maybe even what is possible, but there's no doubt he's going to try. I'm sure he likes making money, and I think profit is a great thing, but it's clearly not his chief concern. He also has a point of view about engineering that I wish most companies shared. He's not afraid to be wrong and change how things are done. I've seen too many projects enslaved by backward thinking.

- Question the constraints, even Nobel prize winners are wrong
- Don’t optimize systems that shouldn’t be there in the first place

- If the design’s taking too long it’s probably incorrect

- What is the question you’re trying to answer?
- Is the question you’re trying to answer incorrect?
- If you can answer the correct question (and do it in a correct way), the answer is relatively easier
- If somebody can show you that you’re wrong, that is great
- If somebody can show you how to make your [design] better, this is a gift

Strangely enough, despite all the 'space geek' talk I think most managed to understand 75 percent of this vid.  Methane is the future! Now how to filter and harvest it from living organisms in a biger scale and more efficiently to the point that the majority of engines requiring a higher combustion efficiency can run on them?  Elon Musk and Mr.Everyday Astronaut, thank you for sharing this conversation!  Reminded me how important it is to apply Newtons 3rd law to the best of ability. When I see rockets or an F16's post combustion,  I mostly think of the crazy thirsty engines and the GPH they must consume, but rarely thought about efficiency and would never have imagined that they could be more than 90 percent efficient. The thing I think Elon was hinting at with the aerospike is the admixture of elements not intended to be part of the  ideal fuel/oxygen combination that the atmospheric exposure that design needs to function smoothly passing through it. It is, if I am thinking this though correctly, atmosphere dependent to adapt its flow shape, and when that atmosphere becomes to small a proportion  of bell analog in inverted form, it is now wasted mass.  The attainable  specific impulse, should an aerospike ever be tested to its full altitude potential may be much less than the fixed combo of sea level and vacuum bells used in Starship. I am especially impressed with the specific impulse SpaceX has achieved with the methanol formulation this early in the program. Also frankly I wonder that since an aerospike seems mostly suited to lower atmosphere conditions if it can be throttled well enough for SpaceX landings. I suppose I will have to wait for your special on the technology to find out.

I think that short conversation pretty well explained the whole problem with aerospikes. At least for me.
With a linear nozzle.
It is nearly impossible to get the fuel and oxidizer to evenly mix and combust as it’s ejected from the combustion chamber.
Like Elon said,
“In a full flow combustion chamber. Things kind of go wherever they want and it doesn’t matter.” Or something like that.
But in an aerospike it does matter.
It is far too easy to end up with too great of concentrations at any point along the linear “spike”. As things are combusting and throwing the surrounding molecules in any random direction.
In a full flow combustion chamber, the walls of the chamber are there to catch and rebound the molecules back into the mix. Where they have a chance to meet up it’s opposing number, whether that be an oxidizer or a fuel and if it doesn’t, then it gets rebounded by another wall and thrown back into the mix.
With an aerospike,
You only have two walls in close proximity to rebound ejected materials. If it goes into the other two directions, there is nothing to rebound ejected materials. That reduces that chances the fuel and oxidizer have to meet up and combust.

Small, but important correction regarding Douglas Adams' "Hitch-hikers guide to galaxy" - the computer used by the mice to find the answer to "life, universe and everything else" (42) was Deep thought. The reason Elon and SpaceX have been so successful at engaging public support is primarily because Elon is so accessible and open. I hope he realises that it's a critical key strength and never looses sight of that, which would be very easy to do in such a complicated industry. The fact that he doesn't try to hide the mistakes or when things go wrong is also in large part the reason for the success they have achieved. The public can relate to that, they aren't dumb contrary to popular belief. They know how enormously complicated space flight is but can collectively recognise that Elon is right in his assertion that we should and must aspire to be more than we are. Which is why they universally support SpaceX in their endeavours.

Regarding the aerospike engine (starting 9:43), although Starship is not an SSTO vehicle, it has the same attributes having both vacuum-optimized and atmospheric Raptor engines. Either one type of engine or the other is always dead weight. The vacuum-optimized engines can only be used in space and the atmospheric engines are only used for propulsive landing. So an aerospike engine could be ideal for both purposes provided it has a high enough level of efficiency and could be on gimbles or use thrust vectoring for propulsive landings. So although Elon discounts the use of an aerospike engine for other than an SSTO vehicle, it could be an ideal engine for Starship which would eliminate half the engines while keeping the same functionality.

What gets Elon going is the same thing that excites me most: reductionism. He demonstrates that way of thinking when he describes eliminating parts that are being optimised when they're not needed, presenting constraints that are assumed to be correct yet are not, and even interdepartmental communication. I wish more people could think like this.
Climb down off your assumptions, then look at things from atoms up.
It was a pleasure to visualize what he described happening in a combustion chamber. Hot gas mixing instead of cold, and how that speeds things up; CH4 vs massive CxHx chains cracking then recombining with oxygen much faster. He has good intuition, as is expected with a reductionist mindset, of physical limitations at the lowest level, and can recognize the actual problems needed to be solved. It's akin to asking the right questions.

Thank you for doing the interview exactly as you did it! At the end you apologize for not asking about the heat-shielding and Suoer Heavy, but we will find out about those soon enough. What you gave us was great insight into Musk & SpaceX's design decision-thinking. The line of questioning about aerospike was spot-on: we got to see how Musk considers alternative possibilities. It helps clarify why the shift to methalox was a bit scary but worthwhile. Enough research had been done on methalox to show that it is feasible and at least 98.5% efficient, but most tech experience has been with the fuels on either side of methalox on the efficiency/manageability trade-off: kerosene on one side, liquid hydrogen on the other. Proving feasibility is  big "sunk cost," it has now been done for methalox, but not fully for aerospike (X-31?). His openness to a substantially different tech was fascinating to watch. Aerospike might never prove out in practice, but Musks willingness to seriously consider it is backed up by his actual choice to shift to stainless steel AFTER building that huge mandrel for the carbon-fiber design.

Best interview with Elon Musk to date. Two people who like to chat about the same passionately.

My thoughts:

1 - I'm surprised that Musk believes that the power of his engines is directionally straight. Since both Newton and Kepler and Einstein have shown that the reality of the Universe is curved. And in curvature the energy moves.

In the same drive of Raptors engines we see how the light diamond is formed. Irrefutable proof that the enegia arrives in a curve to that maximum climax point and continues to curve in the above-mentioned diamonds of light.

2 - The ability of the SkyDiver style flight is the future. Impressive to see how SpaceX is heading with notable chances of success to fly this way.

The Starship MKs will encourage redesigning the SuperHeavy to a SkyDiver approach which will be the resolution of a true beast of transport in the history of mankind.

3 - Although the performance of the Starship was presented as limited, its base is incredibly potent. It is likely that we are facing the first fully efficient SSTO, at least for crew transport.

Only the different models that arise through the implementations and tastes in the design will suffice.

4 - The humility with which SpaceX approaches the community is remarkable. Something that should be imitated in all contexts of life.


5 - I believe that the efficiency jumps of this type of machines are likely to come from greater growth in engineering design but also from the use and cunning that we are able to take advantage of the systems already in play.


The work of EveryDayAstronaut and other influencers is really wonderful, hopefully the mainstream media will be encouraged to support you. I mean it from the bottom of my heart.

Observations:
1. Elon's mouth is constantly trying to keep up with his mind; a sign of true genius.
2. Elon's mantra of "question everything" and looking at someone telling him he's wrong is a gift is yet another reason why his companies are on the leading edge.
3. His excitement and enthusiasm is so obvious while he's talking to you; it's easy to see how much he enjoyed the conversation and would have kept talking if the handler hadn't shown up.
4. The comfort level between the two of you was awesome. Of all of the famous people in the world I could hope to meet, Elon singularly seems to be the person I would take the risk of talking to. He just seems like he could enjoy any good conversation.
5. I couldn't stop grinning like an idiot throughout this whole video - I am so happy for you, Tim. You deserve this! Can't wait for the aerospike video; if it's anything like the full flow video I know I'll be watching it at least 2-3 times.

The reason that switching to Aerospike engines would be better is because then they'd only need 3 Raptors for the Starship, instead of using 3 to haul around another 3 that are only used at certain times (i.e. the 3 sea level engine's are dead weight in space, the 3 vacuum engines are dead weight during Earth landing) so if the Aerospikes can be even relatively close to the efficiency of the current Raptor's bells, then the weight savings from drop half of the engines should be more then equal.

Also given spacex's experience with managing large numbers of engines i doubt they would readily adopt an aerospike nozzle as at higher altitudes the flow interactions from multiple engines could cause severe heating issues. However they could also run multiple "engines" on the same nozzle which could allow for even deeper throttling not to mention the potential for thrust gimballing without the need to move the engine by varying the output of different combustion chambers along the nozzle.

I think it is great what SpaceX and Elon Musk are doing, remember they are standing on the shoulder of giants and they are the offspring of the generation that grew up in the frise of the Space Age.
So at the 0:16 mark we see a lift with a welder welding away IN OPEN AIR, on this supposed "Starship". COM'ON! Anyone with an ENGINEERING degree believes this MOCKUP will be launched into space, then they'll believe anything! This is just simply a PR stunt! Sure it might be a throwaway testbed, but that is all it is! This is just narrated and scripted visuals to drive interest $$$$$$$!
Just look back on the history of WHERE and HOW launch vehicles are constructed and assembled, you certainly WOULD NOT expose a HIGH TENSILE weld joint to open air(And that is for any part of the skin of a ridge form load bearing structure)!
I love the FACT that the "Starship" is Space Shuttle like, and a nod to the proof in concept that the Space Shuttle could've and should've been as a generational design!
